ES6 Initial Impression

03 Mar 2017

One of the main reasons I am so excited to continue learning to master Javascript is the constant evolution of the language. The popularity of the Angular and React frameworks have shown us that this language is here to stay. ES6 is the latest version of the language and has come with some significant updates.

The first thing that caught my attention and probably many others, was the arrow function. My initial impression on this: not a fan. There seems to be many different syntax use cases for it that can get quite confusing if someone is not familiar. Yes, I could learn all the syntax cases but the trade off is another mental tax when reading code when I could’ve just simply typed function. What I do like about the arrow function, however, is the fact that you don’t have to worry about the this binding. For example, instead of using a common lexical scoping hack such as var self = this to grab context for another function, the this binding is implicitly lexical with the arrow.

An ES6 update that I am a fan of are the new let and const declarations. These are block-scoped binding constructs. The let keyword enforces what we have already been doing stylistically with var. For example, putting a var inside an if block - that var is still accessible to the entire scope, but it makes sense to put it there for another developer to see that that var is meant to be used for that if statement. The const keyword is simply a variable that cannot be changed (a getter). I don’t think that just because let is now in the language that we should get rid of var. Both have their place in code and I prefer to write let when I know I want my variable blocked - such as in a for loop, or in that earlier example with the if statement.

Overall I think Javascript is moving in a great direction with these changes. As I learn and start incorporating more ES6 features in my code I will continue to update this blog with my thoughts. Stay tuned!

If you like what you read you can check out my previous posts listed in my archive. Or you can check out my github here.
